newsitem.title: USA: B-52 pilot may be allowed honorable discharge.
newsitem.headline: B-52 pilot may be allowed honorable discharge.

text.p: The Secretary of the Air Force may be willing to allow the nation's first female B-52 pilot, who is under fire for adultery charges, to resign with an honourable discharge, the New York Times said.

In its Thursday edition, the Times quoted unnamed senior Air Force officials as saying that Secretary Sheila Widnall is looking for a way to avoid a high-profile court-martial proceeding against Second Lt. Kelly Flinn.
However, Widnall is in a delicate position because under military rules she is barred from formally offering leniency in exchange for avoiding a trial, the Times reported.
Under usual Air Force rules, individuals facing court martial are allowed to ask to be given the chance to resign, a procedure known as resignation in lieu of a court martial, or R.I.L.O.

"There is some concern the reputation of the Air Force is being unfairly tarnished," one senior Air Force official told the Times. "Widnall would certainly consider the facts in this case, and if the R.I.L.O. came she would most probably accept it. I can't necessarily say a discharge would be honourable, but she would certainly consider the ramifications of the range of discharges."
Flinn is facing charges of adultery, fraternisation, disobeying a direct orer and making a false sworn statement. The charges stem from an affair she has acknowledged she had with a married civilian.
